newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Belgian franc, rates to stay where they are.
newsitem.headline: Belgian franc, rates to stay where they are.

text.p: The Belgian national Bank is knowingly and willingly keeping the Belgian franc at its current relatively weakened position in the run-up to EMU, Belgian analysts said on Friday.
"This looks like a conscious strategy (by the BNB)," said Conrad Fieremans at Kredietbank.
At 1350 GMT, the franc was at 20.6425/27 to the mark, well above its ERM midpoint of 20.6255.
"They prefer to have (Belgian) short-term rates above German ones and the franc slightly weaker than to have it the other way round," Fieremans said.
He noted Belgian central bank governor Alfons Verplaetse had said in February that he was not happy with the fact that Belgian short-term rates were slightly below German ones.
Fieremans said the central bank appeared to believe a steady bond market was at least as important as steady franc and short-term rates.

"They do not want a crisis of confidence (in bonds)," he said, noting that the OLO/Bund yield spread for 10-year paper was consistently very low. It was at eight basis points, against seven at the close on Thursday.
Fieremans said the national bank would stick to its policy of tightening money market liquidity to prevent short-term rates from caving in again.
Activity in the OLO market was morose on Friday ahead of a market holiday in the U.S. on Monday.
But Fieremans noted there was barely any covering of positions ahead of the weekend, with no crucial meetings or data coming up now.
Traders remained surprised by the strength of the French franc and bond market ahead of the first round of elections in France. -- Bert Lauwers, Brussels Newsroom +32 2 287 6815
